title: Greatest Common Factor
text: The greatest common factor amongst the three terms in the expression is 1. So we need to use other approaches.

title: Perfect square
text: Is the first term in the expression a perfect square? How do you rewrite $$4a^2$$ into a perfect square?

title: Perfect square
text: Is the last term in the expression a perfect square? How do you rewrite $$9b^2$$ into perfect square?

title: Formula
text: We can rewrite the expression $$4a^2-12a b+9b^2={\left(2a\right)}^2-12a b+{\left(3b\right)}^2$$. Does it fit the pattern $$x^2-2x y+y^2$$?

title: Finding x
text: If $$4a^2-12a b+9b^2={\left(2a\right)}^2-12a b+{\left(3b\right)}^2$$ fits the pattern $$x^2-2x y+y^2$$, then what is x?

title: Finding y
text: If $$4a^2-12a b+9b^2={\left(2a\right)}^2-12a b+{\left(3b\right)}^2$$ fits the pattern $$x^2-2x y+y^2$$, then what is y?

title: Finding 2xy
text: If $$x=2a$$ and $$y=3b$$, then what is $$2x y$$?

title: Find the pattern
text: If we let $$x=2a$$, $$y=3b$$, then $$2x y=12a b$$, and $$x^2-2x y+y^2=4a^2-12a b+9b^2$$

title: Factor first term
text: Given that $$x^2-2x y+y^2=2\left(x-y\right)$$, how do we factor $$4a^2-12a b+9b^2$$?

subHints.title: Rewrite
subHints.text: Based on the above steps, we observe that when $$x=2a$$, $$y=3b$$, $$4a^2-12a b+9b^2$$ fits the pattern $$x^2-2x y+y^2$$. Given that $$x^2-2x y+y^2=2\left(x-y\right)$$. How do we rewrite $$4a^2-12a b+9b^2$$ as a perfect square?
